Suspected Gastritis.Risk Factors: Helicobacter pylori infection; long-term use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); excessive alcohol consumption; smoking; excessive stress; autoimmune conditions; other diseases such as HIV/AIDS; etc.
Suspected Gastritis.Symptoms: upper abdominal pain or burning sensation; nausea and vomiting; bloating and burping; loss of appetite; black or tarry stools; vomiting blood; etc.

knowledge.Acute Gastritis: Specific irritants or injuries, such as excessive alcohol consumption, severe stress, ingestion of certain medications, food poisoning, or certain bacterial and viral infections, multiple organ failure; Usually appear suddenly and may include severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, haematemesis, black stools, diarrhea, and loss of appetite. Gastroscopy: Lesions of erosion and hemorrhage
knowledge.Chronic Non-atrophic Gastritis:
Gastroscopy: erythema (dot, sheet, strip), rough mucosa, bleeding spots/spots; 
Pathological biopsy:  Inflammation of the gastric mucosa without significant glandular damage or reduction; infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the mucosal layer, but the gastric gland structure remains intact; often associated with Helicobacter pylori infection
knowledge.Chronic Atrophic Gastritis:
Gastroscopy: Atrophic mucosa typically has a pale appearance, with increased visibility of submucosal blood vessels due to thinning of the gastric mucosa and loss of gastric folds;
Pathological biopsy: atrophy of gastric glands (reduction or shrinking of glandular structures), often accompanied by intestinal metaplasia or other morphological changes; reduction in the number of gastric glands, thinning of the gastric wall;
